Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Tayloria Adams

Proposal Number: 1612261

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to develop novel cell-based biosensors and increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Tayloria N.G. Adams is "Novel separation of neural lineage cells to determine progenitor cell characteristics." The host institution for this fellowship is the University of California-Irvine and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Lisa Flanagan.

The goal of this project is to sort and characterize neural stem progenitor cells with a multiple frequency dielectrophoresis (DEP) system, which employs electric fields to induce cell motion based on intrinsic cell properties. More specifically, the Fellow is creating a DEP microdevice to isolate distinct progenitor cells based on their differences in membrane capacitance and using biological assays to determine the critical cell molecules contributing to membrane capacitance. In the central nervous system, neural stem cells form specialized neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes that work together to form neural networks that transmit information. A challenge with neural stem cells is that little is known about their transition from stem cells to distinct progenitor cells on their way to forming final specialized cells. Dielectrophoresis, a technology that relies on electric fields to study cells, offers a solution by providing information about cell's membrane capacitance, which can be used to identify progenitors that will form astrocytes and neurons. However, the molecular components that contribute to membrane capacitance are not well studied. The Fellow's research is enabling the characterization of cell surface molecules that regulate whether a neural stem cell becomes an astrocyte versus a neuron. The Fellow's research fills a scientific gap by explaining membrane capacitance in terms of biological function/characteristics, thereby bridging two disparate fields - cell biology and chemical engineering. Ultimately, the Fellow's studies are helping to uncover important differences in these cells and shed light on the processes that control cell generation during brain and spinal cord formation.

The Fellow is being trained in an interdisciplinary capacity, merging biology and engineering, and is broadening participation of underrepresented groups by increasing minorities in STEM. The Fellow's training includes responsible conduct of research training, career counseling, and professional networking. The Fellow, recognizing the importance of support programs for minority students in academia, is working with an afterschool program, Girls Inc., to broaden participation. As part of this effort, the Fellow is providing girls in grades 5-12 with a biological sciences curriculum designed to explore organ structure and function. The Fellow's contributions include curriculum development, co-teaching, and implementing scholarship/internship application components to introduce students to STEM opportunities. For the girls in this program, the Fellow is reinforcing a positive learning environment, building confidence, and establishing a sense of belonging in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview 

In the central nervous system, neural stem and progenitor cells (NSPCs) have therapeutic potential to treat brain diseases and injuries since they provide neuroprotection and differentiate into neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes. NSPCs expanded for transplantation form a heterogeneous population of cells with varying ratios of progenitors linked to distinct fates, such as neuron progenitors and astrocyte progenitors. Quantitative measures to assess or reduce the heterogeneity of transplanted cells are critical and current marker-based approaches to identify progenitors are limited. The research goals were to (1) develop dielectrophoresis-based microfluidic devices to isolate progenitor cells and (2) develop membrane capacitance as a label-free surface marker. Additionally, the PI worked on an educational program to provide Girls Inc. participants (girls in grades 5-12) with an interdisciplinary science curriculum designed to explore organ structure and function through an after-school program. The major research outcomes fall under the following subtopics.

 

Intellectual Merit

Dielectrophoresis-based cell sorting of NSPCs. Two unique microfluidic devices were explored, the microwell dielectrophoresis sorter, and the hydrophoretic oblique angle parallel electrode sorter (HOAPES), were implemented to sort NSPCs. The microwell dielectrophoresis sorter was used to test whether astrocyte progenitors could be purified from human NSPCs. It was found that low frequencies purified astrocyte progenitors, which display increased membrane capacitance when compared to unsorted human NSPCs. However, sorting efficiency was poor with this device, so we developed the HOAPES device  to continuously sort cells via dielectrophoresis. This device is unique because it has a filter, cell aligner, and oblique interdigitated electrodes. The filter blocks large particles from entering the electrode region. The cell aligner uses fluid flow to direct cells to the microchannel sidewalls. Once cells enter the electrode region for dielectrophoresis cell sorting they either deflect to the outer microchannels or remain focused to the middle microchannel and exit the electrode region. Using this sorting scheme, we obtained two distinct NSPC subpopulations that differed by more than 2-fold enrichment of human astrocyte progenitors in the middle microchannel compared to cells in the outer microchannels. Using this same device to sort mouse NSPCs, we obtained purified populations of astrocyte progenitors from the middle microchannel and neuron progenitors from outer microchannels, realizing the goal of using a single sort for multiple target cells.

NSPC characterization and profile. Sufficiently characterizing stem cell functional behavior and having measures that accurately reflect cell phenotype are essential to the development of reliable transplantation therapies. Therefore, label-free dielectrophoresis has been implemented along with flow cytometry to characterize human embryonic stem cell-derived NSPCs. We found that these NSPCs had batch-to-batch heterogeneity indicated with cell size and membrane capacitance which decreased with increased cell age, providing a dynamic measure of cell function. Interestingly, a strong correlation was found between membrane capacitance and a6 integrin, which is critical for cell migration and differentiation in response to specific extracellular matrix cues. Dielectrophoresis plus flow cytometry provided quantitative assessments of stem cell variability, which will be useful for characterizing cells prior to transplantation. These results begin to link membrane capacitance to cell molecular features.

Cell surface N-glycosylation contribution to membrane capacitance. Progenitor sorting is possible because astrocyte progenitors and neuron progenitors have differing biophysical properties (i.e., membrane capacitance) discernible with dielectrophoresis. The specific molecular components that contribute to membrane capacitance are unknown, but recent evidence suggests that cell surface sugars (glycosylation patterns) contribute to membrane capacitance. Hence, the dielectrophoresis response was characterized and membrane capacitance quantified for NSPCs treated with N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc, activator), or kifunensine (Kif, inhibitor) to manipulate NSPC glycosylation patterns. It was found that NSPCs treated with GlcNAc had increased membrane capacitance (reflected in differentiation) and, unexpectedly, NSPCs treated with Kif increased membrane capacitance (no change in differentiation). Cells treated with Kif lose branched N-glycans but form long chain polylactosamine. Thus, the Kif results may identify a new cell surface sugar affecting membrane capacitance but not cell fate.

 

Broader Impact Outcomes 

Girls Inc. after school program. The PI worked collaboratively with Dr. Lisa Flanagan and Girls Inc. to provide girls in grades 5-12 with a biological science curriculum designed to explore organ structure and function. Topics covered include stem cells, tissue engineering, and hands-on organ dissection. Within this program a curriculum was developed and taught which reinforced learning in a positive environment, encouraged scientific curiosity, built girl’s confidence, and established a sense of belonging in science and engineering. This program served students in Santa Ana and Newport Beach, CA.

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2020
Modified by: Tayloria Adams

NSPCs expanded for transplantation form a heterogeneous population of cells with varying ratios of progenitors linked to distinct fates, such as neuron progenitors and astrocyte progenitors. Quantitative measures to assess or reduce the heterogeneity of transplanted cells are critical and current marker-based approaches to identify progenitors are limited. The research goals were to (1) develop dielectrophoresis-based microfluidic devices to isolate progenitor cells and (2) develop membrane capacitance as a label-free surface marker. Additionally, the PI worked on an educational program to provide Girls Inc. participants (girls in grades 5-12) with an interdisciplinary science curriculum designed to explore organ structure and function through an after-school program. The major research outcomes fall under the following subtopics. Intellectual Merit Dielectrophoresis-based cell sorting of NSPCs. This device is unique because it has a filter, cell aligner, and oblique interdigitated electrodes. The filter blocks large particles from entering the electrode region. The cell aligner uses fluid flow to direct cells to the microchannel sidewalls. Once cells enter the electrode region for dielectrophoresis cell sorting they either deflect to the outer microchannels or remain focused to the middle microchannel and exit the electrode region. The PI worked collaboratively with Dr. Lisa Flanagan and Girls Inc. to provide girls in grades 5-12 with a biological science curriculum designed to explore organ structure and function. Topics covered include stem cells, tissue engineering, and hands-on organ dissection. Within this program a curriculum was developed and taught which reinforced learning in a positive environment, encouraged scientific curiosity, built girl’s confidence, and established a sense of belonging in science and engineering.
